instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message:
MacBook Air 2020 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intel. No corrosion visible on board; tiny bit of corrosion on USB receptacle.

USB stable at 20V, taking 0.02-0.06A.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> stable at 3.3V.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> stable at 3.3V.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 12.3V, pulsing to 12.6 briefly every few seconds.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is at 0V, pulsing briefly to 5V every few seconds.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> is at 0V, pulsing briefly to 3V every few seconds.
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> is at 1.1V, pulsing to 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> is at 1.8V, pulsing to 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message:
Both USB ports have the same behavior?
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Also test with known good battery.

Just in case, try DFU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message:
Yes, both USB ports show the same. All tests were done on just the board alone.

Just measured resistances of some rails and it looks like there are shorts (second number is diode mode measurement):

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 60 kΩ   0.39 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 10 kΩ   0.42
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 2MΩ   0.48
<SIGNAL>PV5V_G3S</SIGNAL>: 1 MΩ    0.42
<SIGNAL>PV3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>: 1.5 MΩ    0.54
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2</SIGNAL>:  6Ω    0.004  (good board: 600Ω   0.35)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>: 27Ω    0.03  (good board: 5+kΩ    0.39)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message: I injected 1.1V into <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2</SIGNAL> (which only drew 0.2A) and let it sit for several hours. The only component that got slightly warm was the T2 chip. Bad news?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message:
[QUOTE="sekidata, post: 93691, member: 28264"]
I injected 1.1V into <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2</SIGNAL> (which only drew 0.2A) and let it sit for several hours. The only component that got slightly warm was the T2 chip. Bad news?
[/QUOTE]
This was a bad idea. Never inject into a cpu/t2 rail. 

This could be a short on any of the SLP/AWAKE rails. 

An open circuit on any of the inductors near the PMU can also cause this behavior. 

See more troubleshooting info for this problem on [URL]https://repair.wiki/w/A2179_2020_MacBook_Air[/URL]  --- " 5v or 20v on the USB-C amp meter with low amperage ; SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages/signals cycling. "

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message:
You have short to ground on two different power rails, wirh 2 common components, PMIC and T2.
If T2 heats, no more history about the culprit.
1.1V injected didn't affect the T2; if still was alive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with pulsing power rails
threads.message: Yup, the shorts disappeared after I removed the T2 chip. Good-bye Air.
